title: Bankruptcy and gambling
question: I took out cash from my accounts before and after I filed bankruptcy. I used some of the cash at the casino and on lottery tickets and I don't have any receipts. Should I be worried that the trustee might consider my case fraud?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Bankruptcy estate,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Fraud,Gaming law,Estates,Inherited Roth IRA and estate planning
answers:
You absolutely need to speak to a qualified bankruptcy lawyer. Gambling debt is one of the trigger points the US Trustee's office and chapter 7 trustee will look at to bring assets into the bankruptcy estate. The source of the accounts is the key to this issue.

Feel free to contact me at my office to discuss. I will spend a some time with you (for free) to determine if I can be of help.

I would be more worried about taking the money out after filing. I hope that it was exempted otherwise, you used estate assets, which is forbidden. Some districts do look unfavorably on gambling (unless you win).

Consult with an attorney now.

[This communication is intended as general information and not specific legal advice, and this communication does not create an attorney-client relationship.]

In some districts spending the money on gambling is considered fraud in the sense that depending on the amount and the source of the money using it for luxuries or wasting an asset that the estaate would have acquired could leadd to the Trustee objecting to a discharge. If you took the money out of an IRA then there should not be a problem because it was an exempt source. In some jurisdictions there is case law that supports the notion that gambling is an illness and the addicted cannot control themselves, so should not be denied the discharge. It will depend on how much and what source the funds came from. If you charged the gambling debts that creditor could also object to the dischargeability of the debt. Consult with your bankruptcy attorney.
